posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9630234
They’re right though, there is a reason that CD drives always have a little actuator screw installed.
https://www.repairfaq.org/sam/odfaq.htm
These drives have their lasers tuned specifically for discs mastered in their respective production facilities, not for the endless consumer grade disc burners out there.
This increases C2 error handling:
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/C2_error
Which increases the workload of the laser by increasing the number of reads over the same data. The higher the workload, the sooner it will wear out, especially for mechanical/moving parts.
CD drives regardless of whether or not they’re burning discs are one of the most likely to fail parts as it is. Ultimately it’s not gonna make a dramatic difference, but it will contribute slightly to it dying faster.
Personally I think this is where an ODE is useful because it’s made with modern parts and is entirely sold state. You don’t need to hunt down old drives or parts to fix one, and as of now their fairly available. When the chip shortage dies down hopefully they’ll be even more plentiful and a bit cheaper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9629970
>To the present day no schizo has ever given any evidence why burnt discs should be any worse for the laser

Because burned disks work on a fundamentally different level than a pressed CD. Pressed CDs have physical pits that the laser bounces off of, you can't just drill pits onto a blank CD like that so burned disks instead have an organic dye that the laser literally burns marks onto. These marks can throw off the laser in a similar method to the pits on a CD, but not in the exact same way, it requires more work for the laser to be able to read them.

Furthermore CDs are not perfect, those microscopic tracks are not all going to all be pressed into a perfect spiral. A CD-R even moreso, especially when we're talking about some 25 year old bargain bin burner and definitely if you are stupid enough to just burn it at the highest speed possible. Even with some autophile-grade thousand dollar burner set to 1x, it will never come close to a pressed CD-R in terms of the microscopic spiral of pits not being all over the place. On top of all this, the motor spindle is not perfect either, certainly not within microscopic-level precision. Even the spindle on just the drive reading the disk is going to wobble, and that's exponentially more wobble when you add in the fact that the disk was burned and the burner's spindle also introduced wobble during the burning process.

What all this means is that a burned disk is leagues below a pressed disk in terms of quality and it requires much more effort to read through all of these significantly higher levels of imperfections.

An optical drive's laser isn't static, it has electromagnets that perform micro-adjustments so it can keep track of said groove of pits (or burned ink in this case) while reading the disk, but the harder it has to adjust the more it's going to wear itself out. This is even worse for the Dreamcast as it's optical drive was never designed to read burned disks or play games off a CD instead a GD-ROM.

>>9630000
I don't have an ODE for my Saturn yet but I don't see why it would?

In the case of the Satiator the MPEG slot should not in any way interfere with the cartridge slot. That slot was designed for people to install a MPEG card into for VideoCD ability, and I would imagine would piss off people if it rendered their cartridge slot unusable. While I have no idea if the two slots interface with each other in any way, one should not in any way block operation of the other without there being a massive screwup.

And in the case of the other ODEs that take the place of the optical drive... they.... they just take the place of the optical drive. They aren't in any way touching the cartridge slot at all. Unless you somehow messed up the install and shorted something without noticing they shouldn't interfere with the cartridge slot in any way.

All this being said, the cartridge slow IS quite picky, especially if it's old and worn out. I have a lot of problems with mine in my un-modded Saturns. Generally I have to push the cart all the way in and then gently raise it out a little for it to work. >>9630204
>A dude did it with the Saturn's media expansion slot, but not nothing is around for that on the Dreamcast.

It's not like every expansion slot in every console is the same. The PS1's expansion slot for example didn't give you full access to the system, which is why the PS-IO still needs modifications to work. The Saturn's slot gives you a lot of access and code execution ability, which is why the Satiator is possible.

I have no idea what level of access the Dreamcast's port gives you, but considering that it was meant for modems and only modems, and the DC was developed years after people saw how the expansion slot on the PS1 was being abused for unofficial and piracy tools I highly doubt it can let you just plug in a device and then take full control and stream game data over the port in place of a disk. If the port can even transfer data fast enough is another issue. I can't find specs on the modem port, but the GD-ROm had a 1.8 MB/s transfer rate.

The Dreamcast also has a serial port meant to link consoles like the PS1 could, and there have been SD adapter devices that make use of this to load games. But IIRC this is buggy and much slower than playing them off the disk drive. It's not clear however if this is because the serial port is that much slower than the disk drive or because of crappy adapters or CPU overhead of reading from the adapter:

https://dreamcast-talk.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=14926

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9631498
>it requires more work for the laser to be able to read them.

It only requires more work if the laser is already damaged. If it is in good working order, it will require the exact same amount of work. Otherwise the CDRs would be incompatible.
And if the laser is already damaged, then it will go out eventually anyway, no matter whether you use originals or CDRs. In fact, the #1 reason for CD-ROM drives being returned as faulty is that the laser is going bad - even without CDRs being used. The only thing this does not affect is Audio CD players, which just interpolate over the read errors. But for a CD-ROM drive you can't do that, so the laser has to be worked literally to death.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9632754
I tested it myself using various media and at various speeds on a PS2 with a Lite-On burner.

The crappy cheap Memorex DVDs I had were much slower to load, at faster speeds the game starting to heavily stutter on FMVs or even just flat out fail to load if you burned too fast.

The Taiyo Yudens fared much better, but they still suffered longer loadtimes the faster the disk was burned, and also had stuttering at absolute max burning speed.

Older systems like a SegaCD could not even recognize a disk being in the console if the CD-R was burned too fast.

Hate to break it to you, but those random bargain bin CDs you burned at 48x are indeed putting more wear and tear on your console's optical drives than if you burned them slower.

>>9632779
>It only requires more work if the laser is already damaged.

Completely incorrect, how a laser reads a pressed cd vs a burned one has zero to do with "the laser being already damaged". the disks work in fundamentally different ways, not only does that alone make them harder for a laser to read them, but all of the additional imperfections I mentioned add further strain to it.

>If it is in good working order, it will require the exact same amount of work. Otherwise the CDRs would be incompatible.

Umm, no. If it was an all-or-nothing deal like that then it would not take more time to properly read a disk the lower quality the media/burn was. The fact that you can see lasers take more work to read a burned disk, and the faster you burn it the more work they take to read it, completely disproves that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9632772
>What is the matter with PS1's, Dreamcast's and to a somewhat similar extent, the Sega Saturn's optical drive that makes them eventually keeling over when repeatedly reading CD-Rs?

CDs were not designed with bit-perfect reading in mind, they were designed for audio, where you could skip over an unreadable bit and still get only an imperceptible loss of fidelity.

CD-ROM requires bit-perfect reading, and they got this working through a bullshit hack made on top of the audio cd standard. As a result, if one single sector has an error, the drive has to read it over and over and over and over until it can make a good read. The optics get raped to death by a single dust mote on the disc.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9632808
>I tested it myself using various media and at various speeds on a PS2 with a Lite-On burner.

I used to work in a repair shop. Every single console or cd player we got, that had issues reading discs, just required the pickups to be fixed up and they worked right for years. Half the time we could just tweak the pot a few degrees and that was that, if that wasn't enough we had to hook it up to a scope to measure the RF waveform and keep adjusting both the tracking and focus gain back and forth until it was within boundaries.
After that they read your "memorex 48x" discs as good as originals.

Except for Playstations where you had to swap out the plastic caddy first.

>Completely incorrect, how a laser reads a pressed cd vs a burned one has zero to do with "the laser being already damaged".
It has everything to do with it. If the gains are not set correctly, it will be unable to either track the pits on the disc or to focus on them. It's why the Playstation was so bad, the caddy was all misshapen and you needed to max out the focus gain which burnt out the optics.

>If it was an all-or-nothing deal like that then it would not take more time to properly read a disk the lower quality the media/burn was

What I meant was the optical drive standard having a set of tolerances and that CDRs fit within those tolerances, hence why they are compatible. But if the drive itself falls out of said tolerances due to old age, it won't matter if you read golden master discs or CDRs, neither will load. Your tests made with consumer grade equipment from an era where CD burning barely became economical, for a console that is known to self destruct its own optics when modchipped, will have no relevance whatsoever in this. It's some GameFAQs tier bullshit argument that completely disregards basic servicing details on the hardware.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633638
I figured it out, there were multiple PC-88 emulators I downloaded and I was using the wrong one.
OP, in case this helps you I got the emulator from here: http://takeda-toshiya.my.coocan.jp/common/binary.7z
The one that worked was called pc8801ma.exe
From the LZH file in the Archive.org torrent, I extracted the folder inside (PC88)M88_212a.zip and then moved pc8801ma.exe into that folder and ran it, then mounted a d88 file in the floppy drive and it worked. I couldn't get M88.exe to work so using that other emulator was the only way I could get it going.

>>9631610
>people forget that the Bond franchise was on life support after the two Dalton films sucked all the fun out of it.
I really don't get people who say this.

I fucking love Roger Moore's stint, his movies are my favorite, and generally he's who I think of when I hear someone say James Bond. They're weird and have this sense of levity and slightly fantastical wonder which captivated me even as a kid, but they were also serious in tone, the stakes and motivations always felt real, even when it got mildly out of hand with Moonraker, the tension was there, and there was some grim violence to back it.

Dalton's 007 is like an opposite to Moore's, and that's why I really love those movies. This James Bond is more grounded and cynical, more dark and brutal, he's far more cold blooded towards his much more cruel enemies, he doesn't hesitate to kill, and there's just far less levity and goofy fun. Some who love Moore's movies hate that, but I love it, BECAUSE it's very different, and because it's closer to the books, straying from that isn't inherently a huge problem, but there's a value in capturing it.
The Living Daylights was probably the most 'realistic' movie yet in the series, with a spy plot which was actually very grounded and well planned, featuring fight choreography which felt quite real, yet also very elaborate and creative, the opening fight with the assassin in the kitchen is incredible in setup and execution, by far the best brawl in the series. Yet it still has that 007 charm, it still has the far out gadgets, it still has the gorgeous girl, it still has the lively music, and the scheming mastermind.

As much as I love Moore's 007, that was a long stint, and it couldn't go on forever, moreover the change in direction was ultimately very good, A View To A Kill was already nudging towards that, and I love that movie for it. Sometimes a series of works alters its direction, and sometimes that doesn't have to be bad.

>>9631610
>They had a lot riding on Goldeneye, and if it had sucked there’d have been no more Bond movies.
Goldeneye is comparatively toned down in 'edge' and brutality to The Living Daylights and License To Kill, and while I think Pierce Brosnan does an excellent job, I also think that as 007 he's just kinda 'so-so' overall. It does however keep up the same grounded tone of the Dalton ones, more so even, but the movie would probably have been very similar if they had gotten Dalton to do it as his last one. The way the brutality was comparatively toned down was likely in regards to the response of many fans to the previous two, and it'd most likely have been the case even with him as the star.

>people were still doing Goldeneye tournaments in the late 2000s. Could you say that about Doom or Quake more than a decade after their releases?
Yeah, actually, there was still some competitive Doom and Quake gameplay by 2003 and 2006, far less than during their heights of course, but that was also the case with Goldeneye, which didn't have much for netplay options for some time. You didn't strictly need to physically travel for competitive Doom and Quake multiplayer.

>>9622582
Yes, the FOV in parts with pre rendered backgrounds is usually very big, with cameras far away from the characters.
This is why models are the way they are, there was no technical reason why they couldn't have used battle models outside of battles.

It is because they kept with the tradition of older FF games: all of them except 6 have closer FOV and more detailed characters in battle than they do in the world. They simply adapted that to 3D.

FF8 broke away from the tradition but as a result you have a much greater percentage of camera point of views that are closer to the characters, using scrolling backgrounds more when the characters move around.

>>9624513
This right here. I don't think it necessarily is a problem specific to random encounters either. It's a general problem with combat in story-centered JRPGs. What used to be the main part of the "story" in dungeon crawlers - i.e. you encounter an enemy that tries to kill you - is now turned into an obstacle that's in the way of the "real" story. By having so much linear scripted story it becomes more obvious that the random encounters aren't part of that story and it becomes just a chore you have to slog through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9626949
Speaking as someone who went through this methodology I don't 100% support it but I did become literate in Japanese.
In my opinion the Anki decks are quite unnecessary. Mine hit me with words like 二十歳 in my first few days. I finally used that word for the first time in my entire life last week, eight fucking years after I was made to memorize it.
Real experience is better than flashcards in every way. I believe the best thing to do is to head into a VN immediately after learning kana.
That said, everyone learns differently, and I have met people who swear by Anki.

I'll be direct: if you love visual novels, learn Japanese.
Going from translated VNs to raw ones is like going from vitamin gummies to meth.
You think you love visual novels now?
Wait until you spend weeks, months getting to know a heroine, falling head over heels for her, and hearing her tell you in her own voice that she loves you too.
When everything finally clicked for me for the first time I turned into a fucking junkie. I would come home from work and do nothing but read VNs for four hours straight. Not because I was a workaholic, or committed to studying, but because it felt that fucking good.
When it's sweet it's ambrosia, it's eudaimonia. It's the best I've ever felt.
It certainly isn't always that good, and you have to put in a lot of work to get there, but you owe it to yourself to read a VN the real way at least once.

>>9631140
二十歳 just stuck out to me as particularly pissing-in-the-wind useless because of how many conditions have to line up for learning it from a flashcard to be useful.
>A character is being introduced
>They are EXACTLY twenty years old
>They are introducing themselves verbally
>There is no accompanying kanji
>You aren't already familiar with the word anyway
I have only seen this set of conditions line up once ever, and it's the テレクラ minigame in 龍が如く0. You have to select dialogue choices written in katakana, Kiryuu is being asked his age by a potential love interest, he happens to be twenty in that game, and so 二十歳 is written there as ハタチ.
Is a situation like that so common you need that card on day 3 of your deck?
I'd much rather spend all my studying time "in the wild" rather than bashing my head against a brick wall of maybe-perhaps-kinda-useful-someday flashcards.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9632868

I'm a proponent of learning japanese through memorizing situational phrases first. Phrases you might encounter in your daily routine and interactions. After you memorize those and common questions/responses THEN learn how all of it is written down.

Anyone's brain is meant to go through that route in formative years. You learn common phrases and prompts then later learn how to write it down. That way it's locked in a different way than by rote memorization of symbols and mental gymnastics about what situations they potentially appear in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9629926
Mostly this, but I would actually say the control scheme of the original is the only reason to play it at this point. Many shit on it because it's so unique and has a pretty deep learning curve until you're used to it. But once you are, no other game is like it. You really feel the difference in the weapons, swinging back and forth with the greatsword versus stabbing up and down with the lance. I understand the people who didn't like it, but to me it's sublime and the thing I missed most about the game on it's sequels.

I am a monster hunter super fan though, it's probably my favorite series of games ever. I maxed the clock at 999 hours on the original long, long before I stopped playing and other than Tri on the Wii and the World/Rise games I've put at least several hundred hours into every one.

Playing the original now would be kind of sad because the online was such a major component but it's still an awesome game regardless and the offline game is quite a complete experience in it's own right. If you like it there's plenty more Monster Hunter out there to jump into including Generations Ultimate which is basically the best the series has ever been and still has a decent player base.

That said, the player bases as in all online games are always a little funny. One thing we still joke about is the first time I actually got my PS2 hooked up online. I almost always use greatsword, but happened to have a hammer on me when I came into the hub. I was HR1 so an online newbie, and the first thing said was "hey welcome to MH! Hammers suck btw" because there was an early (wrong impression that they did) but neither happened to notice the hammer I had was the Breathcore which is the most powerful one in the game.

turn order is mostly dictated by speed/agility stat, with some exceptions/issues. if hans went twice, he probably leveled and the system got confused due to his speed increase. 14 attack to something with 6 defense and only doing 6 damage is due to the 15% land effect defense boost. not sure about your max/tao difference, but i think that there are also damage "ranges" where the precise number can vary by a few points. stat variance was a huge problem in sf1, but sf2 is more reliable. the maps in sf1 suck ass with terrible movement and choke points, sf2 is SIGNIFICANTLY better at this. agility doesnt affect dodge, its that chimeras are a "flying" unit, and flying units have stupid dodge in sf1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633270
>FF1/2
Probably PS1. NES needs to be patched and GBA onwards until PR changes the magic system to a standard MP system.
>FF3
FF3's versions are all so different they may as well be different games. The "smoothest" experience is probably the Pixel Remaster. The 3D version has charm, but has the most differences of the three versions and be ready to grind for job points (which is easy if you know how to do it, but still).
>FF4
has so many versions it's hard to tell really.
SNES needs to be patched because the english version made some changes to make the game easier.
GBA version takes a graphical hit, but allows you control over your party comp towards the end of the game and has some bonus content (of questionable quality)
PSP has "RPG Maker graphics", but retains the GBA version's content.
3D, much like with FF3, has enough differences that it qualifies as its own game.
>FFV
Outside of the PSP version I'm not sure if there's a particularly bad version of V outside of the PS1 version (glitched menus and an 'interesting' script) and the ugly mobile version.
>FFVI
SNES FFVI is buggy, but its either that, the PS1 version or taking a hit in graphics and audio in exchange for bonus content of questionable quality in the GBA version.

Part of it also depends on if you take into account the historical aspect, in that you play them in order to to appreciate how the series evolved. In that case, the originals would be the way to go.

To me, the aesthetic of N64 games comes from the limitations that were imposed on them by the hardware, as well as the art style of the period dictating the overall aesthetic. His art defies both of these things.

The old version would restart the level after certain stars and you would lose all your coins.
It would also prompt you to leave a level when you could no longer continue (e.g. inside the volcano, pyramid, etc.)
This version updates the level after certain events, and uses teleporters to prevent the player ever needing to restart the level.

>>9626385
Might be a different revision. I had a mix of official and unofficial cards and all I saw was socketed. But yes you would need a game bit, but that's true of opening up pretty much anything Nintendo.

And yes, the N64's saving is a mess. Depending on the game it could save to the cart, but also could save to a memory card... you would think then that the memorycard was nonvolatile memory like the PS1... or even to BOTH. Only some of the earliest N64 games that saved to the cart used battery-backed SRAM while just about all later games used one of multiple implementations of different kinds of nonvolatile memory.... while the memorycards were battery-backed. What an idiotic mess. On top of that there was no built-in memory card management application like the PS1 and Saturn had, you had to hold Start while booting up a game that supported memory cards... and there was no standard or guidelines on how to design said manager so they varied wildly in features and what they could or could not do. From only being able to delete saves on controller 1, to supporting copying and/or moving saves, to supporting all 4 controllers, to supporting hot-swapping of cards/controllers or not. It was very un-Nintendo of Nintendo actually to not have an iron grip on exactly what the manager should look and act like. Compare that to the DS where the WiFi configuration application is not built into the DS itself but on the cart of any game that supports WiFi.... which is hard to even realize since Nintendo forced everyone ot use the EXACT same implementation down to it's appearance.

Then it would be at most $2 less if you removed the OLED screen, which then would require you to just guess which of your thousands of memorycards you had currently selected.

You can't remove the WiFi because yet again, the entire thing runs off the microcontroller of an already very cheap and budget WiFi board. It would literally cost more to put a non-WiFi CPU with memory in there.

And the Xstation support literally costs nothing because it's all software.

It's already as stripped down as you can reasonably get. A simple extreme budget WiFi controller is already capable of a lot on it's own, no need to add anything extra that increases the cost. They already did exactly what you wanted, they stripped out the FPGA and it lowered the price. Specifically, it was the ESP32-S3 revision of the board that allowed them to strip out the FPGA and lower the cost.

The ESP32 itself would cost nearly $10. So if you want to build your own OLED-less blind equivalent for $10, here is an ESP32-S3 board: https://www.amazon.com/ESP32-S3-Bluetooth-Internet-Development-ESP32-S3-DevKit/dp/B0BPP28ZFB/

Or just the bare chip if you are good enough to use that: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/espressif-systems/ESP32-S3-WROOM-1-N16/16162647

Have fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9632962
There is a Dreamcast one being worked on.

As for Saturn, that would be extremely messy since it used internal storage. There would be no way to have an "infinite" memorycard like this that lets you swap to different banks of storage without having to solder a few dozen points to the Saturn itself, and it would also likely require modification of the shell to to add buttons/screens to swap the storage.

Best best for Saturn would be memorycard-like carts, which already exist. Of course, those require you to manually copy saves to/from them outside of the handful of games that supported saving directly to them, but with it's default save method being internal there is no real way around that.

SegaCD was the same but nobody seems to care about that. I have no idea what the situation with the "RAM" cartridges on that was like, if games were supposed to all have support for directly saving to it instead of internal or if it was the same situation as the Saturn where you mostly just manually moved saves to/from the cart.

A PS2 should be easy to do, if it doesn't exist already. It's memorycards were essentially a DRMed memory stick. You would need to break the (now 23 years old) DRM, but after that, a standard SD card would do the job... though you would need a bit of additional hardware if you want to have built-in card switching or WiFi or anything like that. I know there there were also unofficial memorycards that were larger than 8MB and the PS2 could read them... but I have no idea if there was compatibility issues with those since Sony never officially made any cards larger than 8MB. (Regardless, a modern one would need to split your SDcard into virtual 8MB cards anyway since nowadays the smallest SDcard you can by is 16GB... and I doubt the PS2 can handle that)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9628280
>>9628293
The Atari 2600 came out and was basically just a glorified pong machine.

Most of the games that came out between 1977 and 1982 for consoles were just "high score" generators. Some simple, rote gameplay mechanic that you repeat as long as you can until you get a "high score", trying to emulate arcade games, ignoring the fact that nobody gives a shit about "high scores" on consoles.

The best games from 1977 to 1982 that still hold up are text adventures and RPG's. Temple of Apshai, Sword of Fargoal, Zork, Wizardry, Akalabeth, and Odyssey: The Compleat Apventure; they all do the complete opposite of what most games back then did, which was try and emulate what the arcades were doing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9630617
>I see a LOT of people talk about how it isn't worth playing today except for nostalgia but I have zero nostalgia for anything Atari and I'm a big fan. Here's some of my favorite 2600 exclusives:

To be fair, there is some merit to that. That's around the era of the console gaming crash, because you had zero quality control for games publishing back then (Nintendo was one of the first to introduce a quality checking system with their Seal of Approval), leading to numerous copy-cat games and an infinite number of below-shovelware titles. On PC it was a bit different, because PC's back then were expensive, and almost exclusively owned and operated by adults, and if you were developing a game for it, you knew that your core audience was going to potentially be more limited and they were going to be more discerning with their purchases.

For consoles though, it was a free-for-all. You had companies and individuals who never knew what a video game was until the year some of those consoles came out, developing video games for them.

Most console games from then are rightfully lost forever to the trash bin of history, and the ones that are left are still mostly shovelware. There's maybe 100 decent titles spread across the Colecovision/Atari 2600/Intellivision/Atari 5200. Of those decent titles, which ones are actually good? Maybe 25.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9632503
>everyone gave a shit about hi scores on consoles

No, they gave a shit about high scores in arcades. High scores on consoles were looked at as being pedantic, which is why you quickly saw the formation of goal-oriented gaming instead of score-oriented gaming, a clear and obvious development to any even tangentially aware of video gaming history.

You can see the individual evolution of console games from 1977 up to 1985 and how they gradually phased out high-scores. The progression of space-shooters from the likes of Asteroids in 1979, up to Elite in 1984, is one of the most obvious progressions of game design one can see.

There's no electronics or anything inside these nintendo multi-AV connectors, just wires crimped straight onto the pins inside the plug. So what you might take away from that fact is

>At the same time, 5$ china cables really have nothing to fuck up aside from potentially poor shielding
>If you REALLY wanted to ensure good shielding, you could just buy a chinese cable purely for the connector and replace the wires with wires of your own choosing
>If you're willing to go the modding route you could instead just mod your SNES/N64/Gamecube to have a standard S-Video port (along with ports for Stereo audio and Composite if you wanted to cut out the multi-AV cable entirely) Literally all you're doing is drilling holes into the case to bolt on the connectors and then wiring them to the pins of the multi-AV out, it's like the minimum definition of a mod. After that just use whatever cables you want with the system.

They're different games.

Puyo 2 is the standard and the best version of it is on the Saturn, although Super Remix on the SNES is pretty good too.

N64 has two Puyo games, Sun and Yon. The former is decent and the second best game in the series though some people bitch about the Sun Puyo RNG. The latter killed Puyo though, adding character-specific abilities was a mistake and fucks up the balance.

And then lastly there's the original Puyo, which was reskinned into Mean Bean Machine and Kirby's Avalance. There's no real reason to play this version anymore since there's no offset rule which makes the gameplay far deeper and more exciting.

average solid platform game from the looks of it. 2d platformer in a 3d environment, like Pandemonium, or the sidescroller levels in Crash Bandicoot. The catch is that since you are a spider, you can walk up on walls and ceilings, which makes some of the paths very trippy. Also you can get weapons like bombs, boomerangs, guns, poison cannons, which turn you into a half-robotic spider with a cannon arm and such. Your default weapon is just a melee attack, so having ranged attacks will help.


Boxart is actually very accurate in that regard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9621252
>This is because for years, graphic designers were always taught that "minimalism = good".
this just isn't true and is a gross oversimplification. graphic design has more intent than that. I work as a graphic designer sometimes and it's not just about making something minimal for the sake of being minimal, it's about what you can communicate through the minimalism. that book cover is clever not because it's minimal, but because it communicates lots of things with little visual prompting. the pencils look like chimneys, so it communicates industry, but it could also be communicating blowing off steam through drawing/making, or perhaps simply the messy nature of making while in industry if we take the pencil scribbles literally. if you use your imagination its really quite clever and this sort of minimal design is great because it doesn't patronise the audience by telling them what to think.

this doesn't excuse the Black Belt box art - that is just bad. there is nothing to interpret and what is there to absorb visually simply doesn't look good. but the idea of creating a consistent design for a console's games is interesting and there's no reason why it can't work. it's up to the boxart's designer to do a good job, and sometimes they did, and sometimes they didn;t

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9624869
>this just isn't true
except it is. up until the 80s, there was a dogma for minimalism in design. later it slowly faded away, but then returned anew after Apple. still to this day there's a deeply instilled belief in designers in the West that "minimalism = classy good design", and that slapping Helvetica Bold on blank space is peak aesthetics, when in reality it looks like store brand products half the time.
>it's not just about making something minimal for the sake of being minimal, it's about what you can communicate through the minimalism.
I agree 100%, but tell that to everyone else. Especially today in the heyday of minimalism, they do exactly that: minimalism for the sake of minimalism.
>but the idea of creating a consistent design for a console's games is interesting and there's no reason why it can't work.
it hardly worked ever for art in general. it didn't work too well for albums, for example. it simply looks soulless, like a furniture catalog.
I agree SOME unification can be good (pic very related), but with vast libraries of distinctive titles, it just won't work too well. not surprising that Nintendo mostly dropped it once they allowed 3rd parties on Famicom.
Most of all, the #1 rule of design is that it should fit the context. They're making games for kids, so they want beautiful and exciting artwork, not drab minimalism of a book for grownups. Notice how everyone on this thread said the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9627481
>when you say there was a "dogma" for minimalism in design up until the 80s are you talking about the swiss style? because there are reasons it looks the way it does, and it never blindly states "minimalism = good".
Yes. And yes, I know its history. Except it started with good intentions, but turned into a very dogmatic approach that was taught in academia. Post-modern design was a reaction to it.
And guess who rejected it first? Advertisers. Music labels. Then one by one people started saying that it looks too sterile, too serious, too soulless. Well, that's because it WAS meant to be sterile and serious. Something that fits traffic signs or medicine boxes, but not video games, you know?
And I'd still argue that by and large, modernists actually did say "minimalism = good". They literally went to great lengths to reduce everything to most basic form.
And no, I'm not shitting on Swiss style, in fact I love it—but likely any style, it should be used at the right places, and it should be done well. Master System artwork is neither of those (not Swiss though, just minimalistic).

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9626008
Computer technology advanced at a lightning pace in the 90s so better tech became available at home for reasonable prices. RAM was a big one where cost dropped quite a bit. MaskROM as well, which is why the N64 started out with 8MB carts and ended with 64MB ones. But the arcade market was also shrinking as more and more people bought home consoles so it stopped being worthwhile to invest in state of the art arcade architectures that made console ports a pain in the ass. Virtua Fighter 3 was running on a super computer but that meant no Saturn port. It was already struggling, even in Japan, but that completely destroyed it.

Niglets here don't understand purchasing power and expenses.
>internet

The massive amount of shit people buy (often for overly inflated prices) now were punchlines in the 90s.
Paying $100/mo for a physical phone and usage is just plain normal now, anything below $75 and the user probably has a busted phone with shit data plan through a sketchy company. If I had ever put the phone bill above $20 in the 90s it would have been my ass on the line.
People now are continually dumping money into intangible shit and always crying about being broke with nothing to show for it.

And most people weren't buying full price brand new vidya on any kind of regular basis. Birthdays, Christmases, and divorces were the major sources on that front. The used market was huge, most games didn't stay at release price for more than a few months, and we borrowed games to trustworthy friends.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9628910
This. The Getaway has a 1:1 recreation of inner London minus a lot of the smaller side streets. It's got licensed businesses that would've been in London circa 2002 as well as licensed cars such as Lexus, Toyota, Honda, Rover, Saab and a few more. I played it for the first time in 2022 and I'm astonished the GTA games caught as much attention as they did back in the day considering how much more focused and technically impressive The Getaway feels. GTA feels so cartoony and nerf and drawn out in comparison. The controls are somewhat jank but the atmosphere and story are very compelling. The Getaway Black Monday is a decent sequel with quality of life fixes but a less focused narrative and they lost a lot of the car licenses. Would recommend both.

At home, in my brother's room, I walked in to see a videogame hooked up to his TV, one I hadn't seen before. It was a Super Mario one, but unlike the NES ones I had played, it was in full 3D, and it was very fast, and very smooth.
I had seen 3D games before, we had Terminator : Future Shock, a game I thought was cool as hell, even though I basically just fucked around playing with cheats or loaded my brother's saves to look at places I was too dumb to reach myself.

That Terminator game was not fast and smooth in the same way though. I mean, it had its hectic gunfights and vehicle sections, but a lot of what you did in that game was sculking around old and dark city ruins or high tech defense installations, with some low tier robots to blast here and there, and occasionally some more intense moments with the big bad robots or Terminators themselves, but it was to a very large part an exploration game, and the limited draw distance/darkness prompted you to proceed carefully.

Super Mario 64 was different. Past the obvious reasons, it's because you didn't have this incredibly short sight radius with danger lurking in the dark, you saw far, you moved fast, and you could scale and climb so many things. Having always liked Super Mario Bros. 3 a lot, an all new Super Mario game which was different to everything else I had ever seen was jawdropping, and that's before we got into the cool graphics or great music and sound. I wasn't very good at the game, wasn't good at any game at all in those days, but I loved just exploring this incredible 3D world and just moving around, interacting with things, and sometimes just playing with Mario's face, because it was real funny.

posts.com:
>>9630028
Also I would soon see another game, Goldeneye 007. Holy fuck, it was one of the coolest games I had ever seen, it was a shooting game like Terminator, but much faster, and starring James Fucking Bond. It had a hundred different guns, you could dual wield machinepistols and rocket launchers. Enemies reacted to what part of their body you shot them, even leading a splat of blood, if you snuck up on a guard and shot him in the asscheek, he'd jump in terror and grab is ass lmao. Some of the death animations were really drawn out and dramatic, as well, and it made the shootouts much more intense, and it was fun miming them at school recess when playing with other kids, sometimes we'd build guns out of Lego, but most of the time just imagining the pistols and machineguns in our hands.

Seeing Quake 2 on PC not long after, that's another which made a huge impression on me. I thought the James Bond game had prettier grafics (and our copy of Quake 2 was pirated so there was no groovy music like in Goldeneye), and having muzzleflashes was always cooler, but the vicious murder cyborgs, big scifi railguns and Miniguns, with colorful lasers and blocky and mean industrial military bases, that had a lot of currency with me. Between Quake 2 featuring special textures for enemies as they got injured, even squeezing off some last shots in their dying throes, or outright getting shot into pieces, and GE64s hit location functionality and elaborate animations, it would actually take quite some time until I was actually impressed by videogame violence again. Sure, some games had pools of bloor and decapitations and stuff, but they should see what the Quake and James Bond games had! Getting to see Doom 2 a year or two later gave little me some more perspective, and changed my life forever.

The monster design of Quake 2 also resonated a lot with me. Look at its final boss, Makron, a cyborg who had a big gun for a left hand, and for a right hand, he had yet another big gun, then for a head, guess what motherfucker, HIS HEAD WAS ALSO A FUCKING GUN.

>>9630102
It was something else. The levels were incredibly elaborate, beyond what I had seen in many other games.
Sure, Terminator had the realistic city ruins, Goldeneye had the lifelike military installations and hydroelectric dams, but Super Mario 64 had these places where you looked around at everything and looked to climb it to see where it took you, these places were all about the platforming, the acrobatics, the parkour, the veritable and sometimes literal mountain climbing. The first person shooters had a bit of that, sort of, but they were mainly about gunfighting, so the environments were designed with that in mind, even Quake 2, which offered some mobility options, didn't have the same open locations, and certainly not the same range of mobility (barring rocketjumping, but I didn't know that yet). Goldeneye had very little for movement options, you couldn't even jump like in Quake 2 or Terminator, and I was actually very disappointed upon learning that, but it didn't preclude me from enjoying that game, and Super Mario 64's extremely versatile and flexible jumping more than made up for that.

The first Bowser stage was real impressive to me, for the more demanding terrain, featuring moving platforms and teeters suspended over the deadly void, all set to an imposing music track. The fight with Bowser had an aggressive guitar theme, and you couldn't punch or jump on him, there was no axe to drop a bridge underneath him, no, you had to circle around him, grab his tail, and then swing that big fucker around, trying to send him into one of those big naval mines. This was an incredibly novel fight sequence to me, and it was a hell of a supreme visual spectacle.

>>9630124
>It was like videogames 2
Almost, lol, particularly to me, who only ever had played NES games, a few Game Boy Games, and a few computer games, most which were 2D. Maybe I saw Sonic once VERY briefly, but for whatever reason Mega Drive was far less common in Sweden (don't know why, when I finally got to play with one, I thought it rocked).
Arcade cabinets (and pinball machines), were borderline banned in this fag country back in 1982, being grouped with slot machines, so they were VERY rare to find. I was robbed of those experiences and thus I never got to see any of those kinds of games until a good bit later.

The interfacing with Super Mario 64 was really novel to me, it was a gamepad, but it had what appeared to be a micro sized flight sim joystick in the middle, which you'd manipulate with the tip of your thumb. Three-prong meme applied, I thought "How the fuck do you hold this thing? Is it made for Quattro from Total Recall?" but my brother showed me how, you grabbed the center one with your left hand, and used my your hand for the right one. Made enough sense to me, fit my hands fine, but what do you do use the left prong for? He said he had no fucking idea, it was just kinda there, maybe it'll make sense for some hypothetical future game (none which we ever had).
The thumbstick was alien to me as well, I wasn't big on flightsims, because only my oldest brother had those, and they were unplayable without knowing all kinds of binds, so I didn't even know how to take off. There wasn't all these buttond in this stick though, none, just some buttons on the controller, the Z trigger under the middle prong was the most surprising one to me.

Fiddling around with it, it was weird, but I was VERY impressed with the wide and fine range of input, it was like a mouse, and it felt fantastic for moving in SM64.

>>9621925
>It can take on a physical form, manifesting as weapons, armor, or sentient beings. The Maverick Virus behaves like an actual virus, spreading through physical space.
The Maverick Virus mutated from the Wily Virus, which was based on the Evil Energy that Wily found in Megaman 8.
According to Duo in MM8, the Evil Energy is actually a sapient alien substance that absorbs evil within robots minds and then multiplies as to infect more robots. Dr. Light found out that performing a full analysis of it was impossible (much like Zero's system). An entity made out of pure energy is an interesting concept since it can be a power source, be translated into electrical signals (and be transmitted as a virus) and even be converted into mass. Due to this method of replication, the original source can only be harnessed by beings of pure evil. The Wily virus made from it probably works in the same manner, "absorbing" Zero's destructive programming when he fought Sigma and had the migraines, and then spreading to Sigma and the rest of the reploids. Only someone who's pure evil could have it in their system and not die from it (like Wily in robot form).

That's why the Maverick Virus is so unorthodox and can do shit normal computer viruses can't.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the plot of X4 put plainly.

Repliforce was created to supplant the need to combat Mavericks due to the growing number of riots and rebellions perpetrated by Sigma and the virus, which the Hunters could barely control on their own, as evidenced in the past three X games. Repliforce's purpose was shown to be inefficient, and the Hunters were itching for a reason to disband them. Sigma noticed this, and began orchestrating the Sky Lagoon incident.

Magma Dragoon was a Maverick Hunter and prideful warrior who's always envied X's superior fighting abilities, believing the latter always hend back whenever they sparred during training sessions. This grudge he harbored against X allowed Sigma to convince him to sabotage Sky Lagoon and become a Maverick, all so he could force X to have a real fight with him, no holds barred. Still, Dragoon's motivation to betray the Maverick Hunters wasn't enough to cause the Repliforce war, as that would come later.

When the Sky Lagoon crashes, X and Zero find evidence of Repliforce presence in the rubble. They also find Colonel investigating the crash site, who claims to be looking for his sister Iris. The Hunters immediately demand him to surrender his weapons and follow them to the Hunter base for questioning (which often ends in imprisonment or decommission for Reploids, as someone has to take the fall until the real culprits are found, if ever. After all, the Maverick virus scare is a good enough prerogative to let the Hunters point fingers at just about anyone despite their own general ineffectiveness). The Maverick Hunters immediately grow suspicious when he refuses - the image of the second-in-command of Repliforce being detained would ruin public opinion on Repliforce and basically guarantee its dissolution through vox populi.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9625818
The Hunters then demand General to disband the Repliforce and turn himself in for inquiry. Years of experience fighting Mavericks fueled the Hunters' concern that Repliforce could become dangerous, should they become infected by the Maverick Virus or grow strong enough to overpower the Hunters themselves.

The Hunters had a solid reason to be worried, but their authoritarian "do as we say or else" attitude was a big fucking insult to a man like General. Before the incident took place, Sigma warned him that this would happen sooner or later, as human beings were growing wary of armed Reploids running around (though General did not recognize Sigma during their meeting, since everyone thought he was dead for good). Sending a Repliforce representative to talk it out with the Hunters wouldn't work, since the Hunters wouldn't even give Colonel, General's right hand man, the time of day. General then decided that Repliforce should simply leave planet Earth and build a reploid colony in a space station. It wasn't a declaration of war so much as a "you don't trust us, so we're leaving" statement. The Hunters, of course, regarded their disobedience as Maverick behavior, and then the fighting began. The "Final Weapon" was originally the space station they wanted to move to, and was only turned into an actual weapon after the Hunters started going after Repliforce.

Even after the war begins, Repliforce officers like Jet Singray were shown evacuating the civilians before carrying out orders to destroy certain locations. Storm Owl's brigade was attacked by the Hunters, including X, who found himself acting just how Sigma wanted him to, when he denied Owl's accusation that the Hunters were corrupt, before executing him with a charged shot to the face.

Meanwhile, Double was sent by Sigma to Hunter base as to disrupt the flow of information and prevent any chance of peace accords between Repliforce and the Maverick Hunters from happening. And so you have Megaman X4.

>>9628239
Putting it into order it goes like this:
>Evil Energy -> Wily Virus (EE + robot reprogramming algorithm) -> Maverick Virus (Wily Virus optimized to explot Reploid design flaws) -> Sigma Virus (Maverick Virus fused with Sigma's digitized AI at the end of X1) -> Zero Virus (Sigma Virus fused with the virus smuggled by Dynamo into the Eurasia space colony and Zero's AI) -> Nightmare Virus (Zero Virus + DNA Program successfully reverse-engineered by Gate) -> Copy Chip (DNA Program of Sigma and many other old Reploids rendered inert and implemented into New Gen Reploids as to make use of the abilities it grants users)
It may sound silly in a work of fiction, but do remember how many strains of COVID we've gotten in like 3 years.
Putting this into perspective, EE being a sapient entitity does lend to the idea that it keeps consuming hosts and evolving much like a virus, jumping from robot to robot, system to system, mechaniloid to mechaniloid, iteration to iteration. Given the X series' overarching theme of robot free will, it does seem like the virus itself is acting on its own free will in a very twisted way, by rending others of their own.
If Wily turning himself into a cyborg holds true or at least plausible, the virus may have even taken over him. After all, his real body was never found. It may even hint at the reason why X and Zero are not allowed to go near the locations where their capsules were found.

RT5X with CRT effect at 8:7 on a modest-but-not-large monitor with a little smudging to soften it slightly. it's not authentic with how it does the masks, but it's idealized for something that targets 1080p. the RT4K will do individual phosphor emulation.

alternatively, having a CRT of any kind that doesn't have fucked (mostly just asymmetry) geometry works. CRT shaders that emulate distortion often go way too far and exaggerate what would be minimized by calibration in the first place.

I did. I remember it being advertised like fuck back in the early 90s on TV but I had no idea what the movie was even about back then. The ads mostly focused on "Hey, look how sexy this cartoon woman is" without explaining much and mostly trying to show off the animation. I recall one of the ad spots being in the middle of The Simpsons and Holli addressing Bart directly during the commercial.

Years later I found out that it was a mix of animation with live action similar to Roger Rabbit and that made me interested enough to go watch it.

The movie was complete shit however. The plot largely makes no sense, is full of contrived convivences that pray you don't think about them too hard, half the "cartoon with live action" scenes are just an animation overlaid over live action that makes no sense whatsoever and feels there just to be there, even when it's trying to explain itself it barely explains itself (e.g. a scene where one of the human characters tries to explain to another human that his fountain pen is an incredibly dangerous weapon in the cartoon world by... spraying ink into a drunk cartoon character's mouth making him even more drunk. How this is supposed to explain how it's dangerous I have no idea), is full of animation blunders like characters talking with their mouths not moving, and pulls a "happy ending" out of it's ass in the last minute by making up a rule about the cartoon world that apparently not even any of the cartoon main characters except for the one explaining it realized was a thing... that again also only works as a happy ending if you don't think about it too hard.

Supposedly it's heavily butchered from what the original creator intended the movie to be like but I have no proof of that other than random YouTube videos on the subject, still feels like even if that is true and it was done how the creator wanted it would have been a mess though.

I mean... it was just like The Mask game for the SNES to me. Nice graphics, kinda a digitized looking Brad Pitt character. But with cartoon powers. His character in the movie stands out to me, He's content to live in Cool World because the real world sucks to him, and he was a human without any cartoon-y powers. But W/E. It tries to capture the look of the movie. With all the mismatched cartoon styles. Cool World is like a doodle/ graffiti world, the main character calls them 'Doodles' in the movie. Holli's origin is from some prison inmate comic book. There's a girl who was originally graffiti on some wall. So it has a clashing art style, and the game tries to imitate that. But despite the presentation of the game, its a bit of a jank platformer with some adventure elements thrown in. better than T2 Judgement Day, maybe not as good as the SNES The Mask? IDK. But I remember seeing image related in magazines advertising the SNES, NES and GameBoy games. the SNES was one of those common bargain bin games. I don't think i ever saw a NES box. I don't have anything to say about the NES game. I don't think I have ever played it.

posts.com: I think UG1-THAW had a constant progression of polish. UG1 opened up the game from the classic arcade play, but I think they didn't get a clear sense of direction until UG2. American Wasteland perfected not only the skating, but also made the off board movement as bearable as it could possibly get. The themes of American Wasteland were cringe in retrospect (but it came out during peak 2000s MTV edge so it didn't feel that way on release if you were younger.) The loading halls was pretty innovative and felt seamless at the time as well. I don't think any of them were bad and they all had their place, but I think THAW was the final product for sure. Also, Idk what >>9620360 is talking about when it comes to THPS3. I think the foundry was just as iconic of a intro level as the other two games had. I actually prefer it over the hanger, and even though THPS3 is my favorite out of them all, I think Warehouse is the most iconic of intro levels ofc.

People care about the story because they played THUG1 and it showed the game could have an interesting story, after the previous games didn't have any. Then all the future games kept the story but did it shittier.
It's hard to say what they could've done differently, because not having a story would've been seen by some as a downgrade, but trying to make another serious story probably would've turned out lower quality. They fucked up by accidentally putting a compelling story in their wacky sports game, there was no way to top it.
You don't play Tony Hawk games for the story, but its story was a significant part of it being a memorable game.

THPS4 fails as a Tony Hawk game by not being fun to play a second time. You can't execute challenges on demand; you have to first talk to the person.
